bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Joseph H. White, February 14, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] gives White advice on employing stegomyia control in limited areas.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Joseph H. White, February 14, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
White
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
February 14, 1922.
/LC
Dear White:
div1.p:
About what we were speaking last night--i. e. that in planning a
campaign for the elimination of yellow fever from a large region in which
it is permanently endemic we should concentrate at the key-points leaving
the places which will free themselves from infection to do so, I think
we should add this proviso:

That when near the close of the work--i. e. when the places we
judged would not free themselves have been freed from infection--if any other
small place shows infection it may and probably will, be advisable to
do Stegomyia control in such small town instead of waiting for it to
free itself. The alternative, of course, is to continue Stegomyia con-
trol in the key-places which might receive infection from this place
until it does free itself from infection--which would in general cost
more than direct sanitary work at the small place in question.

This is analogous to the change of method advisable under certain
circumstances, as at the beginning of an introduced infection. Un-
questionably, the method of election--in general the only one to be con-
sidered--for the elimination of yellow fever is control of Stegomyia
production, yet, when one is reasonably sure that he has found the first
cases of the disease, control of the human host and fumigation to kill
the infected imagoes is advisable and may result in a much quicker re-
sult than if one confines himself to the control of Stegomyia production--
and at less cost.
